Shapely Tank in the Round : Cast on twice the number given for casting on for the front, minus 4 for the stitches that would have disappeared if you were seaming. In other words, 188 sts (96 x 2 = 192 - 4 = 188) for the size 38. Place markers after the first half of the cast on stitches to indicate the sides (on the size 38 that would be after 94 sts) as this becomes important during the short rows, then for separating at the underarms. Now knit the garter stitch border by *purl 1 round then knit 1 round* until there are 3 garter stitch ridges. For the short rows, just pretend the stitches between the markers on one side are the front and follow the directions. After the last short row turn, work back over the stitches, picking up and knitting the wraps with the stitch next to them as you came to them. After that, work on past the side marker and repeat the short row directions for the other side, it now being the back. Then knit all the way around one time, being sure to pick up and knit the wraps that are left over. Doing these short rows in the round leaves half of the wraps on each side un-worked so that's an important step. And, I suspect, the trickiest part of converting this pattern. After this it's a piece of cake. For the side shaping, I simply did a double decrease (there's directions urlLink here ) at the side markers. I used sl 2, k1, p2sso, but if I had it to do over again I'd have used ssk - k1- k2tog instead since it would have matched better with the increases. For the increases, just increase on either side of the markers. Here's a closeup of the shaping ... When the work is the length given in the directions, just pick a side to be the front and work the short row shaping for the bust. Be sure you keep sight of which side is the front now, since once it's divided at the underarm you'll want that bust shaping in the front. ;o) After that work one round all the way around, picking up and knitting those wrapped stitches again, then divide at the underarms. Use the side markers to know where to separate the two pieces. Cast off as in the directions at those markers on both sides and voila! the rest of the directions are as in the pattern since now you'll be working the sides flat, except for one little naggy bit : the numbers aren't entirely correct since you cast on 4 stitches too few. What I did was just follow the directions until the stitch count was correct. In other words, I left out the last two decreases since my stitch count was right (72 sts for the 38) without them. Is this clear as mud? Here's a picture of my Shapely just as I'm starting to work the back half... I hope to get finished today. I tried it on like this last night (tricky with those needles still in it) and was very happy with the results. I can see myself making another one of these!

My questions are: I have to cut the edges to get it the right shape at the top, right? What happens to the short row shaping at the bottom then? Should I cut it off too, or try to angle the cut? If I cut it off, what's the point of doing the short rows at the bottom of the front part (I did the back first to hide my sins)? The extra inches at the bottom would be nice for hip ease, so angling would be preferable, but then the rows won't match up on the sides Jocelyn, um...where are you getting the idea that anything has to be cut? Once you finish the front & back, you sew one shoulder together then pick up stitches around the neckline and work 6 rows of garter stitch. Then you sew the other shoulder together & pick up stitches around the armhole,like for the neck, & work garter stitches. Then the other armhole is worked the same as the first. Sew the side seams, steam to block and you're done. The armholes won't look so huge after you work the 6 rows of garter stitches. Sorry you had to frog so much of it, but I can't wait to see the finished tank. Your color selections a so bright and happy. I'd just go back and count the first row and make sure you have the correct number of stitches. If you do, just work your way up the tank & look at the instructions to try and find where things went wonky. Good luck!

urlLink FO! I finished seaming and weaving in ends in the car on my way home from vacation. Mine is a little tight in the bust but I expected that; otherwise it fits well, if a little clingy. I had an interesting discussion with my fellow-knitter friend on vacation about sizing. She is a skater, and she has been reading up about fitted garment design, as she prepared to sew some skating garb. The information she read said that most patterns (sewing and knitting) are designed for a B cup (though this one claims a C cup). If you are better-endowed than that, you should measure ABOVE the bustline, just at your underarms, to get the chest circumference. I know that for me (34G), it would be a big problem if I had made the pattern in a 41" size (my full bust measurement). Instead, I made the 36" and included bust darts as per the pattern. I was scared to make the darts any longer for fear they would cross one another, so I only did two sets of short rows, for an E cup. That's okay, since I'm breastfeeding and I expect my boobs to return to normal someday, LOL. But anyway, I think the sizing issue may be at fault for some of the folks who had problems. I hate to think of anyone frogging an entire sweater--do you have any friends who are fluffier than you who might be eternally grateful for a handknitted tank top? Could they buy you more yarn if $ is an issue? Anyway, I know how frustrating it is to finish (or nearly) a project and find out it's completely wrong (click on my blog link to see how very well I know this--the other project I've been working on met that fate this week). Make lemonade whenever you can. Photo on actual bod will be forthcoming--DP is asleep so no one to take a pic of me in it!
